name: Minkowski dimension
rephrased: A method to measure how 'rough' a surface is by counting how many boxes of a given size are needed to cover it, and seeing how that number changes as the box size gets smaller.
implication_form: If a set S in R^n is covered by a certain number of boxes of side length ε, then its Minkowski dimension can be defined as the limit (as ε approaches 0) of the logarithm of the number of boxes divided by the logarithm of 1/ε.
solved_by: unsolved (it's a definition, not a conjecture to be solved)
explained: The Minkowski–Bouligand dimension, commonly known as the Minkowski dimension or box-counting dimension, is a defined method for quantifying the fractal dimension of a bounded set \(S\) within a Euclidean space \(\mathbb{R}^n\), or more generally within a metric space \((X, d)\). It is calculated by determining how the number of boxes of a given size needed to cover the set \(S\) changes as the box size decreases. Specifically, if \(N(\epsilon)\) denotes the minimum number of \(\epsilon\)-diameter boxes (or cubes in \(\mathbb{R}^n\)) required to cover \(S\), then the Minkowski dimension \(D_M\) is defined as the limit (if it exists) of \(D_M = \lim_{\epsilon \to 0^+} \frac{\log N(\epsilon)}{\log (1/\epsilon)}\). This limit provides a measure of the 'roughness' or 'complexity' of the set \(S\), often coinciding with the Hausdorff dimension but is generally easier to compute.
related_conjectures: Hausdorff Dimension Conjecture (in various contexts, e.g., Julia sets, self-similar sets)
